entry.et: Middle English, from Old English blāwan; akin to Old High German blāen to blow, Latin flare, Greek phallos penis

def.dt: :to be in motion a breeze blew gently
:to move with speed or force the wind was blowing
:to move or run quickly the linebacker blew past the tackle
:to send forth a current of air or other gas don't blow on your soup
:to make a sound by or as if by blowing
:sound
:boast
:to talk windily
:pant gasp the horse blew heavily
:to eject moisture-laden air from the lungs through the blowhole
:to move or be carried by or as if by wind just blew into town
:erupt explode
:to melt when overloaded often used with out
:to release the contained air through a spontaneous rupture usually used with out
:to set (gas or vapor) in motion the fan blew hot air on us
:to act on with a current of gas or vapor the breeze blew my hair dry
:to play or sound on (a wind instrument)
:to play (as a note) on a wind instrument
:to spread by report
:damn blow the expense
:to drive with a current of gas or vapor the storm blew the boat off course
:to clear of contents by forcible passage of a current of air blow your nose
:to project (a gesture or sound made with the mouth) by blowing blew him a kiss
:to distend with or as if with gas
:to produce or shape by the action of blown or injected air blowing bubbles
:to deposit eggs or larvae on or in
:to shatter, burst, or destroy by explosion blow the safe open
:to put out of breath with exertion
:to let (as a horse) pause to catch the breath
:to expend (as money) extravagantly
:to treat with unusual expenditure I'll blow you to a steak
:to cause (a fuse) to blow
:to rupture by too much pressure blow a seal
:botch 1 blew her lines
:to fail to keep or hold they blew a big lead
:to leave hurriedly blew town
:to propel with great force or speed blew a fastball by the batter
:to become enraged
:to be favorable at one moment and adverse the next
:to release pent-up emotions
:to lose one's composure
:to reveal one's real identity
:to overwhelm one with wonder or bafflement
:to become violently angry
:to go crazy
:to speak idly, misleadingly, or boastfully
:to call public or official attention to something (as a wrongdoing) kept secret usually used with on
:a blowing of wind especially when strong or violent
:brag boasting
:an act or instance of blowing
:the time during which air is forced through molten metal to refine it
:the quantity of metal refined during that time
:cocaine

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English blōwan; akin to Old High German bluoen to bloom, Latin florēre to bloom, flor-, flos flower

def.dt: :flower bloom
:blossoms
:bloom 1b lilacs in full blow

entry.et: Middle English (northern dialect) blaw; probably akin to Old High German bliuwan to beat

def.dt: :a forcible stroke delivered with a part of the body or with an instrument
:a hostile act or state :combat come to blows
:a forcible or sudden act or effort :assault
:an unfortunate or calamitous happening failure to land the job came as a blow
:to dissipate or remove as if with a current of air their doubts were blown away
:to kill by gunfire :shoot dead
:to impress very strongly and usually favorably
:to defeat soundly blew their rivals away in the first game
:minutely detailed a blow–by–blow account
:having blow-dried hair
:being or appearing well-groomed but superficial or vacuous
:to dry and usually style (hair) with a blow-dryer
:to dry hair with a blow-dryer
